{{Infobox Bishop | honorific-prefix = His Excellency, The Most Reverend | name = John Michael D'Arcy | honorific-suffix = | bishop_of = [[Roman Catholic Diocese of Fort Wayne-South Bend|Bishop emeritus of Fort Wayne-South Bend]] | image = | caption = | province = [[Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Indianapolis|Indianapolis]] | diocese = [[Roman Catholic Diocese of Fort Wayne-South Bend|Fort Wayne-South Bend]] | see = | enthroned = May 1, 1985 | ended = November 14, 2009 | predecessor = [[William Edward McManus]] | successor = [[Kevin C. Rhoades]] | ordination = February 2, 1957 | consecration = December 30, 1974 | other_post = [[Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Boston|Auxiliary Bishop of Boston]] (1974-1985)
Titular Bishop of [[Mediana]] (1974-1985) | birth_name = | birth_date = {{birth date|1932|8|18}} | birth_place = [[Boston, Massachusetts]] | death_date = {{death date and age|2013|2|3|1932|8|13}} | death_place = [[Fort Wayne, Indiana]] | buried = | nationality = {{flag|USA|name=American}} | religion = [[Roman Catholic Church]] | residence = | parents = | spouse = | children = | occupation = | profession = | alma_mater = | signature = }} {{infobox bishopstyles | name=John D'Arcy| dipstyle=[[The Most Reverend]] | offstyle=[[Your Excellency]] | relstyle=[[Bishop]] | deathstyle=not applicable |}} '''John Michael D'Arcy''' (August 18, 1932 – February 3, 2013) was an [[United States|American]] [[prelate]] of the [[Roman Catholic Church]]. He was the eighth [[diocesan bishop]] of the [[Roman Catholic Diocese of Fort Wayne-South Bend|Diocese of Fort Wayne-South Bend]], Indiana. He was succeeded as diocesan bishop by [[Bishop (Catholic Church)|Bishop]] [[Kevin C. Rhoades]], who was named to the post by [[Pope Benedict XVI]] on Saturday, November 14, 2009. Until then, Bishop Rhoades had been bishop of [[Harrisburg, Pennsylvania]]. ==Early life and ministry== John D'Arcy was born in [[Brighton, Massachusetts|Brighton]], [[Massachusetts]], to [[Ireland|Irish]] [[Immigration to the United States|immigrants]]. His parents were Michael and Margaret (Moran) D'Arcy. He had three sisters: Mrs. Mary Caprio, Sister Anne, and Mrs. Joan Sheridan. He entered [[St. John's Seminary (Massachusetts)|St. John's Seminary]] in September 1949, and was [[Holy Orders|ordained]] to the [[Priesthood (Catholic Church)|priesthood]] on February 2, 1957. D'arcy is an [[List of people associated with the Pontifical University of St. Thomas Aquinas|alumnus]] of the [[Pontifical University of St. Thomas Aquinas (Angelicum)|Pontifical University of St. Thomas Aquinas ''Angelicum'']] where he studied from 1965 to 1968 earning a [[doctorate]] in spiritual [[theology]]. He served as [[Spiritual direction|spiritual director]] and [[professor]] of spiritual theology at St. John's Seminary from 1968 to 1985, and also as [[pastor]] of [http://www.beverlycatholic.com St. Mary Star of the Sea Church] in [[Beverly, Massachusetts|Beverly]]. ==Episcopal career== On December 30, 1974, D'Arcy was appointed [[Auxiliary bishop|Auxiliary Bishop]] of [[Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Boston|Boston]] and [[Titular bishop|Titular Bishop]] of [[Mediana]] by [[Pope Paul VI]]. He received his [[Bishop (Catholic Church)|episcopal consecration]] on February 11, 1975 from [[Humberto Sousa Medeiros|Humberto Sousa Cardinal Medeiros]], with Bishops [[Thomas Joseph Riley|Thomas Riley]] and [[Lawrence Joseph Riley|Lawrence Riley]] serving as [[Consecrator|co-consecrators]]. He became [[episcopal vicar]] for the [[Merrimack Pastoral Region|Lowell Region]] on July 21, 1981. When serving as auxiliary bishop in Boston, D'Arcy "warned against the Catholic Church’s transfer of pedophile priest [[John Geoghan]] to a new parish, according to the church's own investigators. But Bishop D'Arcy's 1984 letter to Archbishop [[Bernard Francis Law]] about Geoghan’s history of abusing young boys did no good." Geoghan was left in his youth-groups job and "D'Arcy was transferred to Indiana".Lawrence, J.M., [https://www.bostonglobe.com/metro/obituaries/2013/02/05/bishop-john-arcy-who-warned-boston-archdiocese-about-pedophile-priest-dies/5C6KSC9CqCx2JiNXtWc02N/story.html "Bishop John M. D’Arcy, 80; warned against transfer of pedophile to new parish"], Boston ''Globe'', February 05, 2013. Retrieved 2013-02-05. ===Bishop of Fort Wayne-South Bend=== D'Arcy was named [[Roman Catholic Diocese of Fort Wayne-South Bend|Bishop of Fort Wayne-South Bend]], [[Indiana]], on February 26, 1985. Replacing [[William Edward McManus]], he was formally [[Enthronement|installed]] on the following May 1. In March 2009, D'Arcy declared he would boycott the May graduation ceremony at the [[University of Notre Dame]] because [[US President|President]] [[Barack Obama]] would be delivering the [[commencement speech]] and receiving an [[honorary degree]].{{cite news|date=2009-03-24|work=[[National Catholic Reporter]]|title=Protesting bishop won't attend Notre Dame graduation|url=http://ncronline.org/news/politics/protesting-bishop-wont-attend-notre-dame-graduation|last=D'Arcy|first=John}} Noting Obama's "unwillingness to hold [[Pro-choice|human life as sacred]]," he said that "a bishop must teach the Catholic faith 'in season and out of season,' and he teaches not only by his words–but by his actions" and asked Notre Dame if by choosing Obama "it has chosen prestige over truth." He retired in 2009. ==Death and burial== Bishop D'Arcy died on February 3, 2013, in [[Fort Wayne, Indiana]] from cancer at 80.{{cite news |title=Bishop D'Arcy has died |author=Kevin Leininger (contributor) |url=http://www.news-sentinel.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=/20130203/NEWS/130209861 |newspaper=[[News-Sentinel]] |date=3 February 2013 |accessdate=3 February 2013}} Following his death, visitations were held at both [[St. Matthew's Cathedral (South Bend, Indiana)|St. Matthew's Cathedral]] in South Bend and the [[Cathedral of the Immaculate Conception (Fort Wayne, Indiana)|Cathedral of the Immaculate Conception]] in Fort Wayne. The Mass of Christian Burial for Bishop D'Arcy was held on February 8, 2013 at the Cathedral of the Immaculate Conception followed by the Rite of Committal, which was conducted privately with his family in the crypt of the cathedral.http://www.todayscatholicnews.org/2013/02/rest-in-peace-bishop-darcy/ ==See also== *[[List of the Catholic bishops of the United States#Province of Indianapolis]] ==Sources== *[https://web.archive.org/web/20090223224618/http://diocesefwsb.org/jmd.htm Diocese of Fort Wayne-South Bend] *Michael J. D'Arcy obituary, Nashua Telegraph (Nashua, New Hampshire) December 2, 1977 page 2. ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== *[https://www.nytimes.com/2013/02/05/us/bishop-john-darcy-dies-at-80-sounded-alarm.html?src=rechp "Bishop John D’Arcy Dies at 80; Sounded Alarm on Sex Abuse" (limited no-charge access)], New York ''Times'', February 5, 2013. {{start box}} {{s-rel|ca}} {{succession box | title=[[Roman Catholic Diocese of Fort Wayne-South Bend|Bishop of Fort Wayne-South Bend]] | before=[[William Edward McManus]] | after=[[Kevin C. Rhoades]] | years=1985–2009 }} {{succession box | title=[[Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Boston|Auxiliary Bishop of Boston]] | before=– | after=– | years=1975–1985 }} {{end box}} {{Roman Catholic Diocese of Fort Wayne–South Bend|state=collapsed}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Darcy, John Michael}} [[Category:1932 births]] [[Category:2013 deaths]] [[Category:Deaths from cancer in Texas]] [[Category:American Roman Catholic bishops]] [[Category:Roman Catholic bishops of Fort Wayne–South Bend]] [[Category:20th-century Roman Catholic bishops]] [[Category:21st-century Roman Catholic bishops]] [[Category:Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Boston]] [[Category:Clergy from Boston]] [[Category:Saint John's Seminary (Massachusetts) alumni]] [[Category:Pontifical University of St. Thomas Aquinas alumni]] [[Category:Deaths from lung cancer]] [[Category:Deaths from brain tumor]] [[Category:American whistleblowers]]

{{Autism rights movement}}
'''Kassiane Asasumasu''' (formerly known as '''Kassiane Alexandra Sibley''') is a [[Hapa]] and [[Asian Americans|Asian American]] [[Autism rights movement|autistic rights]] activist and blogger from [[Oregon]]. She is also a [[gymnastics]] instructor<ref name=":0">{{Cite news|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/alicegwalton/2011/12/09/living-life-with-autism-ii-perspectives/3/#330b664248f1|title=Living Life With Autism II: Perspectives|last=Walton|first=Alice G.|work=Forbes|access-date=2018-05-22|language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://blogs.plos.org/blog/2016/04/04/repost-why-autism-awareness-is-not-enough-steve-silberman-and-friends-explain-autism-acceptance/|title=Repost: Why "Autism Awareness" is Not Enough: Steve Silberman (and friends) explain "Autism Acceptance" {{!}} PLOS Blogs Network|website=PLOS Blogs Network|language=en-US|access-date=2018-05-22}}</ref> and a hobbyist [[Archery|archer]].<ref name=":1">{{Cite news|url=http://thetacomaledger.com/2016/04/04/wolf-blue-clothing/|title=The Wolf in Blue Clothing - The Tacoma Ledger|date=2016-04-04|work=The Tacoma Ledger|access-date=2018-05-22|language=en-US}}</ref>
Asasumasu is known for deliberately provocative and political writing on [[autism]] on her current and former blogs, and her strong stance against the ideas that autism should be cured, that autistic people are broken, or that non-autistic parents of autistic children have more expertise on autism than autistic people themselves.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.commonwealmagazine.org/night-out|title=A Night Out {{!}} Commonweal Magazine|website=www.commonwealmagazine.org|language=en|access-date=2018-05-22}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://thebodyisnotanapology.com/magazine/at-the-intersection-of-white-privilege-and-disability/|title=At the Intersection of White Privilege and Disability|date=2017-11-29|work=The Body Is Not An Apology|access-date=2018-05-22|language=en-US}}</ref> She is also known for coining the term "neurodivergent" to describe a person with atypical neurological functioning or processes, and "[[neurodivergence]]" to describe various types of atypical neurological functioning or processes, including [[developmental disabilities]], [[Learning disability|learning disabilities]], and [[Mental disorder|mental illnesses]].<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/982501293|title=Authoring autism : on rhetoric and neurological queerness|last=1984-|first=Yergeau, Melanie,|isbn=9780822372189|location=Durham|oclc=982501293}}</ref>
Asasumasu was diagnosed as autistic at three and a half years old.<ref name=":0" /> She was once an editor for the Thinking Person's Guide to Autism, an information and advocacy website catering to parents of autistic children who support the [[neurodiversity]] movement's core belief that autism is not a disease that needs to be cured.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.familycircle.com/blogs/momster/2013/04/03/i-cannot-have-this-conversation-right-now/|title="I Cannot Have This Conversation Right Now."|website=Family Circle|access-date=2018-05-22}}</ref> She is a frequent presenter at autism-related conferences, and has presented on neurodiversity-related topics for the [[Autism National Committee]] in 2008 and 2015,<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.autcom.org/conf2008/schedule.html|title=AUTCOM Conference 2008|website=www.autcom.org|access-date=2018-05-22}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.autcom.org/conf2015/AutCom%202015%20Conference%20Program.pdf|title=AutCom 2015 Conference Program|last=Autism National Committee|first=|date=2015|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> the [[Autism Network International]]'s [[Autreat]],<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://autreat.org/aut13presentations.html|title=Autreat 2013 Presentations|last=Autism Network International|first=|date=2013|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> the [[Autism Society of America|Autism Society]], [[Georgetown University]],<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.heath.gwu.edu/sites/g/files/zaxdzs2346/f/downloads/disability_and_inclusion_in_the_humanities___flyer.pdf|title=Disability and Inclusion in the Humanities|last=Georgetown University|first=|date=November 14, 2012|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.thehoya.com/panelists-discuss-disability-culture/|title=Panelists Discuss Disability Culture|date=2012-11-15|access-date=2018-05-22|language=en-US}}</ref> and the [[Autistics Present Symposium]] at [[Bellevue College]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.bellevuecollege.edu/autismspectrumnavigators/conference-schedule/|title=2017 Autistics Present Conference Schedule :: Autism Spectrum Navigators|website=www.bellevuecollege.edu|language=en-US|access-date=2018-05-22}}</ref>
In 2011, Asasumasu claimed that autism charity [[Autism Speaks]] plagiarized and misattributed her work on [[self-advocacy]] by using quotes from a self-advocacy curriculum she had developed without consent, profiting from her work while opposing the goals of her activism.<ref name=":1" /><ref name=":2">{{Cite web|url=http://timetolisten.blogspot.com/2011/02/autism-speaks-shut-up-and-listen.html|title=Radical Neurodivergence Speaking: Autism Speaks: SHUT UP AND LISTEN|last=K|first=Neurodivergent|date=2011-02-04|website=Radical Neurodivergence Speaking|access-date=2018-05-22}}</ref> Asasumasu's blog post concerning the plagiarism prompted a comment from an individual purporting to be writing on behalf of Autism Speaks.<ref name=":2" />
In 2014, Asasumasu delivered a lecture entitled "DisAbused: Rethinking the Presumption of Caregiver Benevolence" for the D Center (Deaf and Disability Cultural Center) at the [[University of Washington|University of Washington-Seattle]], later delivering the same lecture for [[Georgetown University]]'s Lecture and Performance Series on Disability Justice organized by fellow autistic activist [[Lydia Brown]].<ref name=":3">{{Cite book|url=https://link.springer.com/chapter/10.1007/978-3-319-56901-7_10|title=Religion, Disability, and Interpersonal Violence|last=Brown|first=Lydia X. Z.|date=2017|publisher=Springer, Cham|isbn=9783319569000|pages=163–178|language=en|doi=10.1007/978-3-319-56901-7_10}}</ref><ref name=":4">{{Cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PLrg_LVxfZRfw-XAwKtYI7ChllVZJjB2V7|title=Kassiane Sibley - Disabused - YouTube|website=YouTube|language=en|access-date=2018-05-22}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.disabilityjusticegu.com/events/disability-justice-series/|title=Lecture & Performance Series on Disability Justice – Disability Justice for Georgetown|website=www.disabilityjusticegu.com|language=en-US|access-date=2018-05-22}}</ref> In her lecture, Asasumasu argued that parents, family members, and other caregivers of people with disabilities are presumed to have noble and benevolent intentions at all times, which leads to impunity for abuse and other acts of violence toward those for whom they are responsible, who are also presumed to be incompetent.<ref name=":3" /><ref name=":4" />
In a blog post, Asasumasu described her ethnicity as [[biracial]], [[Hapa]], [[Hāfu|Hafu]], [[Eurasia]]n, [[Mongols|Mongolian]], [[Romanians|Romanian]], [[Japanese people|Japanese]], and [[Croats|Croatian]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://neuroqueer.blogspot.com/2013/09/kassiane-sibleys-open-letter-to.html|title=NeuroQueer: Kassiane A. Sibley's Open Letter to Identity Police (Part 1)|last=Grace|first=Elizabeth J. (ibby)|date=2013-09-13|website=NeuroQueer|access-date=2018-05-22}}</ref>
== Selected works ==
* Kassiane Sibley, "Help Me Help Myself: Teaching and Learning," in ''Ask and Tell: Self-Advocacy and Disclosure for People on the Autism Spectrum'' (edited by Stephen M. Shore), pp. 33–64 (2004)<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/56316353|title=Ask and tell : self-advocacy and disclosure for people on the autism spectrum|others=Shore, Stephen M., 1961-|isbn=1931282587|location=Shawnee Mission, KS|oclc=56316353}}</ref> * Kassiane Alexandra Sibley, "Advocacy: Everyone Can Do It", in ''Loud Hands: Autistic People, Speaking'' (edited by Julia Bascom), pp. 309–312 (2012)<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/823510362|title=Loud hands : autistic people, speaking|others=Loud Hands Project,, Autistic Self Advocacy Network,|isbn=9781938800023|location=Washington, DC|oclc=823510362}}</ref> * Emily Thornton Savarese, Amanda Baggs, Jamie Burke, Sharisa Kochmeister, Sue Rubin, Phil Schwarz, Stephen Shore, Kassiane Sibley, & Tracy Thresher, "[http://dsq-sds.org/article/view/1073/1239 Self-Advocate Roundtable with Members of AutCom]," in ''Disability Studies Quarterly'' 30(1) (2010).<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Savarese|first=Emily Thornton|date=2009-12-14|title=What We Have to Tell You: A Roundtable with Self-Advocates from AutCom|url=http://dsq-sds.org/article/view/1073|journal=Disability Studies Quarterly|language=en|volume=30|issue=1|issn=2159-8371}}</ref>
== References == <references />
== External links ==

Ability to breathe fire
Skin hot enough to burn others when touched
Healing factor
Teleportation
Flight }} '''Kid Devil''' (real name '''Edward Alan "Eddie" Bloomberg'''), currently known as '''Red Devil''', was a [[superhero]] in the [[DC Comics]] universe. ==Publication history== Created by [[Alan Kupperberg]], [[Dan Mishkin]], and [[Gary Cohn (comics)|Gary Cohn]], he first appeared in ''Blue Devil'' #14. ==Fictional character biography== {{Plot|section=y|date=December 2009}} ===Origin and early heroics=== Eddie had the good fortune of being a [[gofer]] in his Aunt Marla's film company. He met [[Blue Devil (DC Comics)|Blue Devil]] on a film set, and became quite a fan of the hero, dreaming about one day becoming Blue’s sidekick. Edward snuck into Blue Devil's workshop at night and, using his prodigious knowledge of electronics, created a [[powered exoskeleton|battlesuit]] incorporating the designs of the Blue Devil suit. Even though Blue Devil did not want a sidekick, Eddie was determined to make a go at being a hero. As "Kid Devil", he assisted his hero in foiling an airplane hijacking, and later helped defeat one of his enemies, the Vanquisher. After these adventures, his parents left Eddie's education and supervision to professors at the Institute of Hypernormal Conflict Studies. After Eddie's Aunt Marla died in a helicopter crash, Eddie attempted to live up to her name and succeed in the movie business. His attempts failed, however, and Eddie continued to have adventures as Kid Devil. He helps [[Young Justice]]'s assault on Zandia, a small country that has become a refuge for supervillains.''Young Justice'' #49-50 (December 2002) ===Changes and Titans=== Since the events in ''[[Infinite Crisis]]'', Eddie has tried to join the [[Teen Titans]] with little success. Pulsar helps Eddie get into a project [[Lex Luthor]] has been using to give normal humans superpowers. However, Eddie fails because of "psychological problems". One evening, Eddie is visited by a cloaked figure, who gives him a candle. Eddie then goes to find his friend, [[Zachary Zatara]]. Zatara, being a magician, knows a little about magic and tells Eddie that the candle is a '' 'demon stick' '', forged in demon's blood. Zatara tells Eddie that if you light it, it will take you to its creator (which could be anyone). Eddie asks if, after teleporting them both to the creator, Zatara could just teleport them back. Zatara brags that he could, even though his magic could only affect things, not people. Not knowing of Zatara's inability to teleport anyone anywhere, Eddie decides to light it and the two are taken to [[Neron (DC Comics)|Neron]]. Neron makes a deal with Eddie, transforming him into a ''new'' Kid Devil. Neron's magic gives Eddie a new, [[demon]]ic appearance and inherent superpowers. As part of the deal, Eddie will not lose his soul to Neron if he can still trust Blue Devil by his 20th birthday. Before Eddie leaves, Neron tells him that it is Blue Devil's fault that his Aunt Marla died. Zachary helps Eddie join the Teen Titans, they battle [[Kid Crusader]], and Zachary promises to keep his secret. [[One Year Later]], a rift has formed between Eddie and Zachary. Though Eddie is still friendly with Zachary, the boy magician wants nothing to do with Eddie or any of the other Titans. Eddie also forges a bond with [[Rose Wilson]], as both new members feel like third-string Titans. For many months, Eddie tells the Titans of multiple daily [[phone call]]s to Blue Devil as his way of confirming that "everything is fine".''Teen Titans'' (vol. 3) #34 (May 2006) On a Titans mission, Eddie is [[disemboweled]] by [[Plasmus]] and the [[Emergency medical technician|EMT]]s are unable to help him. The new [[Doom Patrol]] arrives and take Kid Devil to their HQ for treatment, where the [[Chief (comics)|Chief]] heals Eddie while also attempting to manipulate him into joining the Doom Patrol (as he has done to the other DP members). During the operation, the Chief revealed to [[Elasti-Girl]] that Kid Devil is not truly a demon by nature, but rather his powers are the result of metahuman gene manipulation. Robin calls Blue Devil, as he is on Kid Devil's emergency contact list, but finds that the number is out of order. Robin eventually tracks down Blue Devil and tells him the situation. Blue Devil tells Robin that he has not seen or spoken to Eddie in two years. When Robin confronts Eddie about his relationship with Blue Devil, Eddie confesses he was only pretending in order to better fit in with the Titans. The Chief's manipulation is stopped by both the Titans and the other members of the Doom Patrol, which makes Eddie feel as if he is finally accepted as a Titan since they stood up for him. He also tries rekindling his bond with Blue Devil, but the man does not show up to a meeting to which Eddie invited him. Later, Eddie finally finds and confronts Blue Devil. Blue Devil admits that he was to blame for his Aunt Marla's death and that it was an accident. As part of a deal with Neron for gaining fame and fortune, Blue Devil was asked to destroy an unmanned electrical power station. Despite Blue Devil's various precautions, a resulting power surge accidentally killed Marla, who was scouting the nearby area for a film. Eddie storms off before Blue Devil can explain further, telling Blue Devil to stay far away from him. Now having lost his trust in Blue Devil, Eddie knows that he will lose his soul to Neron. Still, Eddie decides to make the best of his remaining years by having a good time with his friends. He comforts himself by saying that, at least, he has Marla's memory and that Neron cannot take that away from him. However, it is revealed that Neron is holding Marla's soul captive.''Teen Titans'' (vol. 3) #42 (February 2007) Kid Devil is attacked by Kid Crusader, who vows to "save" him from Neron by turning Eddie back into a human and killing him. Kid Crusader appears to succeed when he exorcizes the demon from Eddie and returns him to his human form, but the demon is now bound to Kid Crusader himself. When given the choice later to either return to his demonic form or stay human, Eddie chooses his demonic form, not wishing to damn anyone else (even his enemy) to his fate as Neron's protégé.''Teen Titans'' (vol. 3) #43-44 (March-April 2007) ===''Titans Tomorrow''=== In ''Teen Titans'' #51 (vol. 3), the ''[[Titans Tomorrow]]'' (a possible future version of the current Titans team) arrive in the present to aid the Teen Titans against [[Starro]]-controlled villains. Kid Devil is shown as part of the team, now known as '''Red Devil'''. He claims that even though the loss of his soul to Neron at 20 was bad, the power he receives far outweighs the consequences. Eddie initially watches as Ravager battles alone against [[Rampage (DC Comics)|Rampage]] and [[Livewire (DC Comics)|Livewire]], before betraying his older self in order to aid Rose. Later, Rose, Red Devil, and Eddie return to the Titan's Lair (home of the original Teen Titans), where they meet with [[Blue Beetle (Jaime Reyes)|Blue Beetle]]. There, Eddie learns that he is supposedly destined to murder the Blue Beetle some point in the future. Shortly after Eddie, Rose, and Jaime find themselves surrounded by an army of Titans led by [[Lex Luthor]] before they all battle against an invading army of Starros. Thanks in large part to Blue Beetle's powers and Robin and [[Wonder Girl (Cassie Sandsmark)|Wonder Girl]] managing to supposedly alter Robin's future (and thus alter the future of the Titans as a whole), the army of Titans is defeated. However, prior to his vanishing, Red Devil warns Eddie against trusting Blue Beetle. ===Terror Titans=== In ''Teen Titans'' (vol. 3) #56, a group of supervillains under the leadership of the new [[Clock King]] began a systematic assault on the Titans. With Wonder Girl, Blue Beetle, Ravager, and [[Tim Drake|Robin]] away and [[Miss Martian]] still reeling from the battle with her future counterpart (whose mind is revealed to have taken refuge in Megan's), Eddie decides to throw a party in [[Titans Tower]] and invites several Titans fans. The party quickly gets out of hand when the guests trash the place, go through personal items, and prank call [[Batman]]. Lectured by all members of the team (except Miss Martian, who had left for the week to resolve her own problems), Eddie goes into town with one of the guests, who reveals himself to be Dreadbolt, the son of [[Bolt (DC Comics)|Bolt]]. A fight ensues and the arrival of the rest of the [[Terror Titans]] puts a quick end to the battle. In the aftermath, Kid Devil finds himself chained to a wall and severely injured, captive of the Clock King, who then begins shattering his self-confidence telling him that [[Rose Wilson]] could not care less about his status, encouraging him to accept his place as a monster. Brought to the [[Dark Side Club]] as a challenger, he is imprisoned in the same cell in which [[Miss Martian]] is later brought, who finds him reduced to a rampaging, savage monster due to his physical and mental ordeal. M'Gann tries unsuccessfully to undo the damage, but Eddie is brought to face Hardrock in a death match. ===Red Devil=== After the crisis with the Terror Titans is settled, Kid Devil is saved, and with the help of the Teen Titans, is able to rebuild his mental sanity while he is nursed back to health. Still trying to prove himself, he begins searching for [[Shockwave (comics)#DC Comics|Shockwave]], who is rampaging apparently without a pattern throughout America, deliberately hiding from Robin his suspicions to avoid burdening the decimated Titans with an apparent [[wikt:wild-goose chase#Noun|wild goose chase]]. He is forced then to accept the unwilling cooperation of Blue Beetle, who, demonstrating to be a better detective than he and a more seasoned fighter despite his later induction into heroics, goes on alone. In a fit of anger spurred by his inability to come in and fight Shockwave, he finally unlocks the full might of his demonic powers, as demonstrated by [[Titans Tomorrow|his future counterpart]], teleporting effortlessly from Salt Lake City to Denver and melting off Shockwave's exoskeleton with a touch. Kid Devil is able to resolve his jealousy issues about Ravager when he learns that Blue Beetle had no interest in her at all. He then honors his newfound maturity by taking the [[sobriquet]] of ''Red Devil''. Jaime happily teases Eddie about his new costume, hinting that while in the ''Tomorrow'' history they were sworn enemies; at present, they have a budding friendship signified by Eddie giving Jaime the playful nickname ''"Bug-Butt"'' which Jaime reciprocates by calling him ''"Sizzle-Shorts"''. Around this time the events of ''Final Crisis'' happen, Eddie becomes one of the last few super-powered resistance members operating out of the time-tossed Justice League Watchtower. The [[Miracle Machine]] restores everything back to normal.''Final Crisis'' #7 (2009) Unfortunately, soon after Blue Beetle joins the team, Miss Martian, with whom Eddie had become increasingly closer, has opted to leave the team due in large part to her being merged with her evil future self. Still, Eddie appears to have become more content with his life amongst the Titans and has become closer to Blue Beetle and his girlfriend [[Traci 13]]. During a Christmas trip to New York, Miss Martian appeared to him to wish him a Merry Christmas and promised that she would return soon. Soon after, the Titans began having a membership drive, with Red Devil teleporting to each potential hero so as to offer them membership. Unfortunately, none seem available or willing to join. The stress of multiple 'ports eventually causes Eddie to pass out on his return to the tower. On the night that follows, Robin opts to leave the team shortly before [[Brother Blood]] returns from Hell. During the battle against him, Blood manages to absorb the demonic power from Eddie, leaving him human again and supposedly free of Neron's debt. ===Powerless=== Eddie, now powerless, is offered by [[Kid Eternity]] a chance to travel to [[Hell (DC Comics)|Hell]] and see his contract with Neron in an attempt to regain his powers. Learning that he had not signed the contract, he finds that Neron tapped into his metagene, which activated his demon-like powers. [[Blaze and Satanus|Blaze]], having won the [[Reign in Hell|war in Hell]], offers Eddie a new contract, with his demonic powers now irrevocable, but with the same price of servitude as Neron's contract. Kid Eternity intervenes and summons Eddie's Aunt Marla. Marla convinces Eddie not to take the contract.''Teen Titans'' (vol. 3) #68 (March 2009) Eddie continues to be a member of the team, but his ability to help is unclear. To add insult to injury, Eddie is asked by new Titan recruit [[Static (DC Comics)|Static]] if he is the "team janitor" due to his lack of abilities.''Teen Titans'' (vol. 3) #69 (April 2009) During the prelude to the '''''Deathtrap''''' crossover, Eddie dons his old mechanical costume to combat the Tower's defense mechanisms, which had been overridden by crazed former Titan [[Jericho (comics)|Jericho]].''Teen Titans Annual'' #1 His way of helping, which [[Bombshell (DC Comics)|Bombshell]] repeatedly makes fun of, is to be the eyes and ears for the Teen Titans when the new [[Fearsome Five]] reform under the [[Calculator (comics)|Calculator]]. However, he is also seen as helping the team through communications and coordinating missions at Titans Tower. He later died saving the city from a radioactive man who was about to explode while the other Titans were putting down a prison riot. It appears that this was all part of the Calculator's plan to get revenge at the Titans for the previous death of his son [[Wendy and Marvin|Marvin]] and the injury of his daughter [[Wendy and Marvin|Wendy]].''Teen Titans'' (vol. 3) #74 (August 2009) ===The New 52=== In September 2011, [[The New 52]] rebooted DC's continuity. In this new timeline, Eddie Bloomberg first appears as the godson to Blue Devil.''DC Presents'' #12 ==Powers and abilities== [[File:Kiddevildc.png|thumb|right|150px|Kid Devil in his power suit from ''Blue Devil'' #14, artist Paris Cullins]] Originally, Eddie wore a devil suit which gave him enhanced strength and agility, near impenetrable armor, a weapons system that included a bright light burst effect, exploding bubbles, night vision, and mini-gills. He also had a rocket trident which could propel him through the air for distances of up to several miles and could emit flames and/or electric shocks. [[One Year Later|After the events]] of ''[[Infinite Crisis]]'' and ''[[52 (comics)|52]]'', Eddie has a [[demonic]] appearance and inherent abilities, both granted to him by the demon-lord [[Neron (DC Comics)|Neron]]. His new form gives him a capacity to breathe fire, enhanced strength and endurance, and an ability to heal from non-fatal wounds ten times faster than a human. When punched in the stomach, Eddie cannot control his fire breath. Eddie's blood is now a thick [[gasoline]]-smelling liquid, his breath is hotter than fire, his own skin is able to cause burns (being at 200 degrees) and he has been seen to be able to increase this, to the point of his skin turning white hot. He can fire streams of flame from his hands, has retractable wings underneath his arms that help him glide, possesses a prehensile tail, and his internal temperature is 600°. He learned how to create portals of fire through which he can travel long distances. When Dr. Niles Caulder, leader of the Doom Patrol, tended Kid Devil's injury, he revealed that the young hero is not a demon nor are his powers supernatural in nature, despite being granted by a demon. Rather, Neron activated Eddie's [[metahuman]] gene which gave him his powers. However, like a real demon, his skin still burns while inside a church due to his deal with Neron. Eddie lost his powers due to an attack by the new Brother Blood, Sebastion, shortly before sacrificing himself to save the other Titans. ==Other versions== ===''Flashpoint''=== In the alternate universe of ''[[Flashpoint (comics)|Flashpoint]]'', Kid Devil is a member of the Resistance.''Flashpoint: Deadman and the Flying Graysons'' #3 (August 2011) ===''Final Crisis''=== A spacebound Blue Devil met a futuristic version of Edward who was saved from being erased from existence. Blue Devil also encountered a Nazi version of him. ===''Tiny Titans''=== Kid Devil appears in ''[[Tiny Titans]]'' as a toddler. [[Raven (DC Comics)|Raven]] often has to babysit for him. Her father, [[Trigon (comics)|Trigon]], shows more of an interest in Kid Devil than in Raven when she does. He thinks of Kid Devil as "a cute little baby". Raven often tells Trigon that Kid Devil is not a baby, he is a little kid. However, Trigon does not listen and only babies Kid Devil more. Kid Devil does not speak in this series and relies solely on visual gags. In one issue, Kid Devil travels to the center of the Earth with [[Terra (comics)|Terra]], [[Hotspot (character)|Hotspot]], and [[Beast Boy]], and meets [[Etrigan the Demon|Etrigan]]. ==References== {{reflist}} {{Teen Titans}} [[Category:Fictional characters who have made pacts with devils]] [[Category:Comic book sidekicks]] [[Category:DC Comics metahumans]] [[Category:DC Comics superheroes]] [[Category:Comics characters introduced in 1985]] [[Category:Fictional characters from California]]

{{BLP sources|date=April 2014}} {{Infobox person | name = Kristin Cavallari | image = Kristin Cavallari - Flickr - nick step.jpg | image_size = | caption = Cavallari in September 2010 | birth_name = Kristin Elizabeth Cavallari | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1987|1|5}} | birth_place = [[Denver]], [[Colorado]], U.S. | residence = [[Nashville, Tennessee]], U.S. | education = [[Laguna Beach High School]] | occupation = Television personality, fashion designer, actress | years_active = 2004–present | spouse = {{Marriage|[[Jay Cutler (American football)|Jay Cutler]]|June 8, 2013}} | children = 3 }} '''Kristin Elizabeth Cutler'''<ref name="Marriage">{{cite web|url=http://www.nbcchicago.com/blogs/grizzly-detail/Jay-Cutler-Kristin-Cavallari-Tie-the-Knot-210608211.html|title=Jay Cutler, Kristin Cavallari Tie the Knot|first=Maggie |last=Hendricks|publisher=[[WMAQ-TV]] ([[NBCUniversal]] | location=Chicago| date=June 21, 2013|accessdate=June 7, 2013 | archivedate= September 5, 2014 | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20140905235124/http://www.nbcchicago.com/blogs/grizzly-detail/Jay-Cutler-Kristin-Cavallari-Tie-the-Knot-210608211.html | deadurl =no}} citing {{cite web | url = https://twitter.com/KristinCav/status/343069432735756288 | title=Im officially Kristin Elizabeth Cutler!!!!! | first= Kristin| last=Cavallari | publisher= Kristin Cavallari verified [[Twitter]] account | date= June 7, 2013}}</ref> (née '''Cavallari'''; born January 5, 1987)<ref name=yahoobio>{{cite web|title=Kristin Cavallari biography|url=https://tv.yahoo.com/person/kristin-cavallari/biography.html|publisher=Yahoo!|accessdate=April 11, 2014 | archivedate= November 13, 2013 | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20131113010115/http://tv.yahoo.com/person/kristin-cavallari/biography.html}}</ref> is an American [[Celebrity|television personality]], [[fashion design]]er, and [[Acting|actress]]. Born in [[Denver]], [[Colorado]], she attended [[Laguna Beach High School]] as a teenager after spending junior high and freshman year living in [[Barrington, Illinois]]. In 2004, Cavallari came to prominence after being cast in the [[reality television]] series ''[[Laguna Beach: The Real Orange County]]'', which documented the lives of her and her friends.
After moving to [[Los Angeles]] to pursue an acting career in 2006, Cavallari appeared in several television series as minor characters.
Cavallari is married to American football player [[Jay Cutler (American football)|Jay Cutler]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.etonline.com/exclusive-kristin-cavallari-jokes-shell-be-single-parent-while-jay-cutler-plays-miami-dolphins|title=EXCLUSIVE: Kristin Cavallari Jokes She'll Be a 'Single Parent' While Jay Cutler Plays for the Miami Dolphins|work=Entertainment Tonight|access-date=2017-09-29|language=en}}</ref>
==Early life== Cavallari was born in Denver, Colorado,<ref name=yahoobio /> one of two children of Judith Eifrig and Dennis Cavallari.<ref name=stn>{{cite web|title=Descendants of Friedrich Wilhelm Eifrig|publisher=Genealogy.com|year=2009|url=http://familytreemaker.genealogy.com/users/e/i/f/Eric-W-Eifrig/GENE7-0004.html|accessdate=November 3, 2010| archivedate= July 13, 2015 | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20150713203435/http://www.genealogy.com/ftm/e/i/f/Eric-W-Eifrig/GENE7-0004.html | deadurl=no}} Note: Source spells first name "Kirsten".</ref> She is of German and Italian descent.<ref>{{cite web|title=Stars' Family Holiday Traditions: Kristin Cavallari|url=http://www.usmagazine.com/celebrity-news/pictures/stars-family-holiday-traditions-20123110/25835|website=US Magazine|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121117134628/http://www.usmagazine.com/celebrity-news/pictures/stars-family-holiday-traditions-20123110/25835|archivedate=November 17, 2012|quote=...the former reality star does Christmas big with her Italian family. 'We would always do a big Italian feast. My dad would make homemade raviolis and all kinds of things...My mom is German...'}}</ref> <!-- When her mother divorced her father, her older brother, Mike, moved with their father to [[Laguna Beach, California]], while she moved with her mother to the village of [[Barrington, Illinois]], a suburb an hour northwest of [[Chicago]]. She attended Barrington Station Middle School, and graduated on to [[Barrington High School (Lake County, Illinois)|Barrington High School]]. After difficulties adjusting to a new life with a stepfather and stepbrother, Cavallari moved to California to live with her father. There, Cavallari was enrolled at [[Santa Margarita Catholic High School]] for her freshman year. After she attended a Driver's Education course through [[Laguna Beach High School]], her father enrolled her in Laguna Beach High School.{{citation needed|date=May 2014}} -->
==Media career== [[File:Kristin Cavallari.jpg|thumb|upright|left|Cavallari in September 2008]] Cavallari was in her [[High school junior|junior]] year of high school when the first season of ''[[Laguna Beach: The Real Orange County]]'' began production. At the time, she was involved in an on-and-off relationship with [[High school senior|senior]] [[Stephen Colletti]]. Cavallari's romance with Colletti caused a rivalry with another cast member, [[Lauren Conrad]]. The love triangle became one of the series' central plot lines.
In May 2009, Cavallari confirmed she would be joining the cast of ''Laguna Beach'''s spin-off series, ''[[The Hills (TV series)|The Hills]]''.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://latimesblogs.latimes.com/showtracker/2009/05/its-official-kristin-cavallari-joins-the-hills.html|title=It's official: Kristin Cavallari joins 'The Hills'|date=May 14, 2009|work=[[Los Angeles Times]]|accessdate=May 22, 2009| archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20090517140043/http://latimesblogs.latimes.com/showtracker/2009/05/its-official-kristin-cavallari-joins-the-hills.html | archivedate = May 17, 2009|deadurl=no}}</ref> She made her first appearance on the series during the fifth season's midseason finale on May 31, 2009, at [[Heidi Montag]] and [[Spencer Pratt]]'s wedding, where she caught the bouquet. The second half of the season premiered on September 29, 2009, with Cavallari assuming the position of former main cast member and narrator Conrad. Despite originally signing a deal with [[MTV]] to appear in two additional seasons following the fifth, the sixth and final season concluded on July 13, 2010.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ew.com/article/2009/05/14/ew-exclusive-la|title=Exclusive interview: 'Laguna Beach' star Kristin Cavallari on joining 'The Hills'|last=Stack|first=Tim |date=May 14, 2009|work=[[Entertainment Weekly]]|accessdate=May 22, 2009 | archivedate= April 6, 2015 | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20150406112111/http://www.ew.com/article/2009/05/14/ew-exclusive-la |deadurl=no}}</ref>
Cavallari was on the [[Dancing with the Stars (U.S. season 13)|13th season]] of [[American Broadcasting Company|ABC]]'s ''[[Dancing with the Stars (U.S. TV series)|Dancing with the Stars]]'' and partnered with two-time champion, [[Mark Ballas]]. She was the third to be eliminated.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/live-feed/dancing-with-the-stars-kristin-cavallari-voted-off-244436|title='Dancing With the Stars'' Kristin Cavallari: Why I Got Voted Off (Video)|work=The Hollywood Reporter|access-date=2017-09-29|language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://abcnews.go.com/blogs/entertainment/2011/10/kristin-cavallari-voted-off-dancing-with-the-stars-in-shocking-elimination/|title=Who's Gone on 'Dancing With the Stars'?|last=News|first=ABC|website=ABC News|language=en|access-date=2017-09-29}}</ref>
After ''Laguna Beach'', Cavallari headed to Los Angeles and <!--attended the Loyola Marymount University for few months. She--><ref name=":0">{{Cite web|url=https://www.biography.com/people/groups/famous-alumni-of-loyola-marymount-university|title=Famous Loyola Marymount University Alumni|website=Biography|language=en-us|access-date=2018-09-24}}</ref> signed on the [[UPN]] [[reality television]] series ''[[Get This Party Started]]'', which premiered February 7, 2006. The series was canceled after airing two episodes. She appeared on one episode of another [[UPN]] series, ''[[Veronica Mars]]'', and went on to guest roles on series including ''[[CSI: NY]]'', ''[[Cane (TV series)|Cane]]'', and ''[[Adventures in Hollyhood]]''. In 2006, she signed on as Crystal in the [[horror film|horror]] film ''[[Fingerprints (film)|Fingerprints]]''.
In 2008, she had a supporting role as Summer in ''[[Spring Breakdown]]'' alongside [[Amy Poehler]]. The film was released straight-to-DVD on June 2, 2009, and received mixed reviews. She also starred in the independent film ''[[Green Flash]]'' with [[Torrey DeVitto]]. In 2009, she starred in the independent American high school comedy film, ''[[Wild Cherry (2009 film)|Wild Cherry]]'', as Trish, which also starred [[Rumer Willis]]. She also starred in the straight-to-DVD film, ''[[National Lampoon's Van Wilder: Freshman Year]]'', as Kaitlyn. The film was released July 14, 2009, to mixed to negative reviews.{{citation needed|date=June 2014}}
In March 2012, Kristin commented her first Oscars with the E! team and in 2014, began 'hosting the half-hour fashion/lifestyle trends show called ''The Fabulist'' alongside Orly Shani (Fashion Star).'<ref name=":0" /> Kristin is also passionate about food and decided to write a cookbook called ''True Roots - A Mindful Kitchen with more than 100 recipes Free of Gluten, Dairy and Refined Sugar''. The book made it on the ''New Yorker's'' best-selling list at number three.
On April 4, 2018, [[E!]] announced that Cavallari would be getting her own reality show, ''[[Very Cavallari]]''. It premiered in summer 2018 and followed "Kristin as she opens the flagship store and Nashville headquarters of her rapidly growing fashion and lifestyle brand Uncommon James".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.eonline.com/shows/very_cavallari/news/924947/kristin-cavallari-opens-up-her-nashville-life-in-new-e-docu-series-very-cavallari-watch-a-first-look-now|title=Kristin Cavallari Opens Up Her Nashville Life in New E! Docu-Series Very Cavallari!|last=Malec|first=Brett|work=E! Online|accessdate=April 4, 2018}}</ref> The show was renewed for a second season on August 23, 2018. [https://www.bustle.com/p/very-cavallari-was-renewed-for-season-2-but-that-might-be-bad-news-for-the-hills-fans-video-10227523]
==Charity work and public image== Cavallari has been involved in the "Until There's a Cure" [[public service advertising]] campaign, to raise awareness and funds for [[AIDS]] and [[HIV]] research and vaccine development.{{citation needed|date=April 2014}} In 2006, Cavallari appeared in ads for [[PETA]],<ref>{{cite web|title=Kristin Cavallari: Try Telling Him It's Just a Little Trim|url=http://www.peta.org/?s=kristin+cavallari#foobox-2/0/cavallariAD72.jpg?20131014104311|publisher=[[PETA]]|accessdate=11 April 2014}}</ref> and has also appeared as a celebrity spokesperson for "We Are Ellis Island", a campaign for the restoration of [[Ellis Island]].{{citation needed|date=April 2014}} In February 2009, she posed for the [[NOH8 Campaign]] in support of gay marriage.<ref>{{cite web|title=Kristin Cavallari, Mams Taylor, & Jennifer Gimenez|url=http://www.noh8campaign.com/article/kristin-cavallari-mams-taylor-jennifer-gimenez|publisher=NOH8 Campaign|accessdate=11 April 2014|date=23 February 2009}}</ref>
In January 2010, she traveled to [[El Salvador]] to do [[charity (practice)|charity]] work. In March 2011, Cavallari traveled to [[Kenya]] to do charity work with the [[non-profit organization|nonprofit]] One Kid One World.{{citation needed|date=April 2014}}
In March 2014, Cavallari drew national criticism for refusing to vaccinate her children, a decision her husband, Jay Cutler, and she based on fears of a [[connection between childhood vaccination and autism]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.foxnews.com/entertainment/2014/03/14/kristin-cavallari-defends-decision-not-to-vaccinate-her-son/ |title=Kristin Cavallari defends decision not to vaccinate her son |date=March 14, 2014 |publisher=[[Fox News]] |accessdate=July 13, 2015 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150125094835/http://www.foxnews.com/entertainment/2014/03/14/kristin-cavallari-defends-decision-not-to-vaccinate-her-son/ |archivedate= January 25, 2015 |deadurl=no}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last=Eby|first=Margaret |date=March 19, 2014 |url=http://www.nydailynews.com/entertainment/gossip/kristin-cavallari-defends-anti-vaccination-decision-article-1.1726819 |title=Kristin Cavallari defends anti-vaccination choice: 'We feel like we're making the best decision for our kids'|work=[[Daily News (New York)|Daily News]] |location=New York City |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140917161537/http://www.nydailynews.com/entertainment/gossip/kristin-cavallari-defends-anti-vaccination-decision-article-1.1726819 |archivedate=September 17, 2014 |deadurl=no}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last=Takeda |first=Allison |date=March 19, 2014|url=http://www.usmagazine.com/celebrity-moms/news/kristin-cavallari-defends-anti-vaccine-stance-were-making-the-best-decision-for-our-kids-2014193 |title=Kristin Cavallari Defends Anti-Vaccine Stance: 'We're Making the Best Decision for Our Kids' |work=[[Us Weekly]] |archivedate=May 12, 2015 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150512043452/http://www.usmagazine.com/celebrity-moms/news/kristin-cavallari-defends-anti-vaccine-stance-were-making-the-best-decision-for-our-kids-2014193 |deadurl=no}}</ref>
From 2015–2016, the former website [[Gawker]] ran a series of daily articles on Cavallari for a streak of 415 days.<ref>{{cite news|last=James|first=James|url=http://www.ibtimes.com/gawker-editor-chief-alex-pareene-we-wont-be-garbage-buzzfeed-or-humorless-vox-2190229|access-date=August 24, 2016|date=November 18, 2015|website=International Business Times}}</ref> The series, by Allie Jones, was called "500 Days of Kristin", although it ended after just 415 days, with the publication of Cavallari's book ''Balancing in Heels''. By treating Cavallari's quotidian [[Instagram]] posts as newsworthy, the series appeared to gently mock the culture of celebrity women on social media.
==Personal life== [[File:Kristin Cavallari 2014 NBC Universal Summer Press Day (cropped).jpg|thumb|upright|Cavallari [[pregnant]] with her second child in April 2014]] Cavallari began dating then-[[Chicago Bears]] quarterback Jay Cutler in late 2010,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.people.com/people/article/0,,20429994,00.html | last =Garcia | first = Jennifer|title=Caught in the Act!| date = September 29, 2010 | work=People}}</ref> and they became engaged in April 2011. They called off the engagement in July 2011,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.people.com/people/article/0,,20512593,00.html | title= Kristin Cavallari and Jay Cutler Call Off Engagement| first=Jennifer |last=Garcia |date = July 24, 2011| work=People.com}}</ref> but reconciled in November 2011.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.people.com/people/article/0,,20549737,00.html | title= Kristin Cavallari & Jay Cutler Are Engaged ... Again!| first=Dahvi |last=Shira |date = November 30, 2011| work=People}}</ref> Cavallari and Cutler wed on June 8, 2013, in [[Nashville, Tennessee]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.people.com/people/article/0,,20708092,00.html| title= Kristin Cavallari Tells All About Her 'Absolutely Perfect' Wedding Day| first=Julie|last=Jordan|date = June 12, 2013| work=People}}</ref> They have three children: sons Camden Jack (born August 8, 2012),<ref>{{cite web |url = http://celebritybabies.people.com/2012/08/08/kristin-cavallari-jay-cutler-welcome-son-camden-jack/ |title = Kristin Cavallari and Jay Cutler Welcome Son Camden Jack |work = People |date = August 8, 2012 |first = Anya |last = Leon}}</ref> Jaxon Wyatt (born May 7, 2014)<ref>{{cite web|title=Kristin Cavallari and Jay Cutler Welcome Son Jaxon Wyatt|url=http://abcnews.go.com/Entertainment/kristin-cavallari-jay-cutler-son-jaxon-wyatt/story?id=23625364|publisher=ABC News|accessdate= May 7, 2014|first=Lesley |last=Messer}}</ref> and daughter Saylor James (born November 23, 2015).<ref>{{cite web|last1=Rayne|first1=Naja|title=Jay Cutler and Kristin Cavallari Welcome Daughter Saylor James|url=http://celebritybabies.people.com/2015/11/23/jay-cutler-kristin-cavallari-welcome-daughter-saylor-james/|website=People|accessdate=November 23, 2015|date=November 23, 2015}}</ref>
In June 2018, Cavallari and Cutler put their mansion in [[Nashville]] up for sale for $7.9 million. The mansion is seen in numerous scenes of ''[[Very Cavallari]]''.<ref>{{cite web |title=Kristin Cavallari and Jay Cutler Selling $7.9M Nashville Home Featured in Upcoming Reality Show |url=https://www.realtor.com/news/celebrity-real-estate/kristin-cavallari-jay-cutler-nashville/ |website=realtor.com |publisher=realtor.com |accessdate=31 July 2018}}</ref> The couple purchased a cheaper mansion in Nashville for $4.2 million in April 2018.<ref>{{cite web |title=Exclusive: We Found Kristin Cavallari and Jay Cutler's 'Forever Home,' and Just ... Wow |url=https://www.realtor.com/news/celebrity-real-estate/we-found-kristin-cavallari-jay-cutler-new-house/ |website=realtor.com |publisher=realtor.com |accessdate=31 July 2018}}</ref>
Her brother, Michael Cavallari, was found dead on December 10, 2015, having died of hypothermia following a car crash.<ref>{{cite news|last=Puente|first=Maria|url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/life/tv/2015/12/10/kristin-cavallaris-brother-found-dead/77107878/|title=Kristin Cavallari's brother found dead|newspaper=[[USA Today]]|date=December 10, 2015|accessdate=December 10, 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.foxnews.com/entertainment/2016/02/10/death-kristin-cavallari-brother-ruled-accidental.html|title=Death of Kristin Cavallari's brother ruled accidental|accessdate=August 24, 2016|website=Fox News|date=February 10, 2016}}</ref>

{{Expand Chinese|馬堅|date=February 2017}} {{Infobox Muslim leader | name = Ma Jian | image= | image_size=200px | native_name = Mǎ Jiān/馬堅 | birth_date = {{Birth date|1906|6|6|mf=y}} | birth_place = {{QING}}, Shadian, [[Gejiu]] | death_date = {{Death date and age|1978|8|16|1906|6|6|mf=y}} | death_place = {{PRC}}, [[Beijing]] | other_names = Muḥammad Mākīn as-Ṣīnī, Makin | nationality = [[China|Chinese]] | ethnicity = [[Hui]] | region = [[Yunnan]] | profession = Translator, professor, journalist | denomination = [[Sunni Islam]] | party = [[Communist Party of China]] | main_interests = Translation of [[Confucianism|Confucian]] works into Arabic, translation of [[Islam]]ic texts into Chinese | notable_ideas = [[Islamic socialism#Islamic Marxism|Compatibility between Islam and Marxism]] | notable_works = Chinese translation of the [[Qur'an]] | education = Shanghai Islamic Normal School | alma_mater = [[Al-Azhar University]] | teachers = [[Hu Songshan]] | students = [[:de:Zhu Weilie|Zhu Weilie]]}} {{infobox Chinese |t = 馬堅 |s = 马坚 |p = Mǎ Jiān |w = Ma Chien |altname = [[Courtesy name]] |t2 = 子實 |s2 = 子实 |p2 = Zǐshí |w2 = Tzu-shih }} {{Islam and China}} {{Chinese name|[[Ma (surname)|Ma]]}} '''Muhammad Ma Jian''' ([[Gejiu]], 1906 – [[Beijing]], 1978) ({{lang-ar|محمد ماكين الصيني}} ''{{transl|ar|DIN|Muḥammad Mākīn as-Ṣīnī}}'';<ref name="VersteeghEid2005">{{cite book|author1=Kees Versteegh|author2=Mushira Eid|title=Encyclopedia of Arabic Language and Linguistics: A-Ed|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=SuNiAAAAMAAJ&pg=PA382|year=2005|publisher=Brill|isbn=978-90-04-14473-6|pages=382–}}</ref> English translation: Muhammad Ma Jian the Chinese) was a [[Chinese people|Chinese]] [[Islam]]ic scholar and translator of Muslim [[Hui]] ethnicity. He is notable for translating the [[Qur'an]] into [[Chinese language|Chinese]] and stressing compatibility between [[Marxism]] and [[Islam]].<ref>{{cite thesis |last=Mao |first=Yufeng |date=2007 |title=Sino-Muslims in Chinese Nation-building, 1906-1956 |type=Ph.D. diss. |publisher= George Washington University, 126-127}}</ref>
== Early years == Jian was born in 1906 in Shadian, a village in the [[Gejiu]] county of [[Yunnan]]. This was a majority-Hui village that would later be the site of the infamous [[Shadian incident]] during China's [[Cultural Revolution]]. When Jian was six years old, he was sent to the provincial capital of [[Kunming]], where he would receive his primary and secondary education until the age of 19.<ref>{{cite news |last=Amrullah |first=Amri |date=June 15, 2015 |title=Muhammad Ma Jian, Intelektual Muslim Modern Cina |trans-title=Muhammad Ma Jian, Muslim Intellectual of Modern China |url=http://www.republika.co.id/berita/dunia-islam/islam-digest/15/06/15/npz6cw-muhammad-ma-jian-intelektual-muslim-modern-cina-1 |language=Indonesian |newspaper=Republika |location=Jakarta |access-date=February 15, 2017 }}</ref> Following his graduation, Jian returned to his hometown of Shadian to teach at a Sino-Arabic primary school for two years - an experience which he did not enjoy. This was followed by a stint of study under [[Hu Songshan]] in [[Guyuan]], a city in the Hui region of [[Ningxia]].<ref>{{cite book |last=Aubin |first=Françoise |editor-last1=Dudoignon |editor-first1=Stéphane A. |editor-last2=Hisao |editor-first2=Komatsu |editor-last3=Yasushi |editor-first3=Kosugi |title=Intellectuals in the Modern Islamic World: Transmission, Transformation and Communication |publisher=Routledge |date=2006 |pages=260–261 |chapter=Islam on the wings of nationalism: the case of Muslim intellectuals in Republican China |isbn=978-0415549790}}</ref> He then went to [[Shanghai]] for further education in 1929, where he studied at the Shanghai Islamic Normal School for 2 years.<ref>{{cite news |last=Ciecura |first= Wlodzimierz |date=April 28, 2015 |title=Bringing China and Islam Closer: The First Chinese Azharites |url=http://www.mei.edu/content/map/bringing-china-and-islam-closer-first-chinese-azharites |newspaper=Middle East Institute |access-date=February 15, 2017 }}</ref>
== Study in Cairo == Following the [[Japanese invasion of Manchuria]] in 1931, Jian was sent by the [[Government of the Republic of China|Chinese government]] to [[Al-Azhar University]] in [[Cairo]], [[Egypt]], to cultivate relations with Arab nations.<ref>{{cite news |last=Haiyun |first=Ma |date=May 10, 2013 |title=Go West at What Cost? China’s Pivot on Middle East Studies |url=https://islamicommentary.org/2013/05/haiyun-ma-go-west-at-what-cost-chinas-pivot-on-middle-east-studies/index.html#_ftn4 |newspaper=ISLAMiCommentary |access-date=February 15, 2017}}</ref> He was a member of the first group of government-sponsored Chinese students to study there - which included men who would later become leading Chinese scholars of Arabic and Islam, such as Na Zhong.<ref>Ciecura.</ref> While in Cairo, he contacted the [[Muslim Brotherhood]]-affiliated Salafi Publishing House, which agreed in 1934 to publish one of his works - the first full-length book in [[Arabic]] on the history of [[Islam in China]].<ref>{{cite journal |last=Benite |first=Zvi Ben-Dor |date=2008 |title=Nine Years in Egypt: Al-Azhar and the Arabization of Chinese Islam |journal=HAGAR Studies in Culture, Polity and Identities |volume=8 |pages=3}}</ref> A year later, Jian translated the ''[[Analects]]'' into Arabic. Whilst in Cairo, he would also subsequently translate several of [[Muhammad Abduh]]'s works into Chinese, with the assistance of [[Rashid Rida]],<ref>Ciecura.</ref> as well as [[:fr:Husayn al-Jisr|Husayn al-Jisr]]'s ''The Truth of Islam''.<ref>{{cite journal |last=Chen |first=John T. |date=2014 |title=Re-Orientation: The Chinese Azharites between Umma and Third World, 1938-1955 |journal=The Journal of Asian Studies |volume=34 |issue=1 |pages=35 |doi=10.1215/1089201x-2648560}}</ref> To promote Chinese interests in the context of the [[Second Sino-Japanese War]], Jian was sent to [[Mecca]] in early 1939 as part of a [[hajj]] delegation alongside 27 other students - a journey on which they spoke to [[Ibn Saud]] about the determination of 'all the Chinese people' to resist the Japanese.<ref>{{cite journal |last=Mao |first=Yufeng |date=2011 |title=A Muslim Vision for the Chinese Nation: Chinese Pilgrimage Missions to Mecca during World War II |journal=The Journal of Asian Studies |volume=70 |issue=2 |pages=386–387 |doi=10.1017/S0021911811000088}}</ref>
== Return to China == Jian returned to China in 1939. There he edited the ''Arabic-Chinese Dictionary'', while translating the ''[[Qur'an]]'' and works of [[Islamic philosophy]] and [[Islamic History|history]]. He also became a professor of Arabic and [[Islamic studies]] at [[Peking University]] in 1946, a role in which he oversaw the introduction of the first Arabic-language courses in the [[Chinese higher education|Chinese higher education system]].<ref>{{cite journal |last=Haiyun |first=Ma |date=2006 |title=Patriotic and Pious Muslim Intellectuals in Modern China: The Case of Ma Jian |journal=The American Journal of Islamic Social Sciences |volume=23 |issue=3 |pages=57}}</ref> At Peking University, he would train many of the next generation's most prominent Chinese [[Arabist]]s, such as [[:de:Zhu Weilie|Zhu Weilie]].<ref>Ma (2013).</ref> His initial translation of the Qur'an's first 8 volumes was completed in 1945, and after being rejected by Beijing publishing houses in 1948, this was published by Peking University Press a year later.<ref>{{cite thesis |last=Spira |first=Ivo |date=2005 |title=Chinese Translations of the Qur'ān: A Close Reading of Selected Passages |type=MA diss. |publisher=Oslo University |url=http://folk.uio.no/ivos/files/MA_Thesis_IvoSpira.pdf |access-date=February 15, 2017}}</ref> Following the Communist victory in the [[Chinese Civil War]] and the proclamation of the People's Republic of China, he was also elected as a member of the [[People's Political Consultative Conference]] in 1949.<ref>Ciecura.</ref> In 1952, another edition of his Qur'an translation was published by [[Shanghai]]'s [[Commercial Press]],<ref>{{cite book |last=Waardenburg |first=Jacques |editor-last=Akiner |editor-first=Shirin |title=Cultural Change & Continuity In Central Asia |publisher=Routledge |date=2009 |pages=340 |chapter=Islam in China: Western Studies |isbn=978-1136150340}}</ref> and Jian became one of the founders of the [[Islamic Association of China]].<ref>{{cite book |last=Guanglin |first=Zhang |date=2005 |title=Islam in China |location=Beijing |publisher=China Intercontinental Press, 77}}</ref> As part of this role, Jian also aimed to increase public awareness of Islam - which he did by publishing several articles in newspapers such as the [[People's Daily]] and the [[Guangming Daily (China)|Guangming Daily]].<ref>{{cite book |last=Gao |first=Zhanfu |editor-last1=Yijiu |editor-first1=Jin |editor-last2=Wai-Yip |editor-first2=Ho |title=Islam |publisher=Brill |date=2017 |pages=73–74 |chapter=Studies of Islam in China in the Twentieth Century |isbn=978-9004174542}}</ref> He also published a translation of [[:fy:Tjitze de Boer|Tjitze de Boer]]'s ''History of Philosophy in Islam'' in 1958.<ref>Gao, 74.</ref> Due to his linguistic skills, he served as a high-level interpreter for Chinese officials such as [[Zhou Enlai]], whom he enabled to speak to [[Gamal Abdel Nasser]] at the [[Bandung Conference]].<ref>{{cite book |last=Benite |first=Zvi Ben-Dor |editor-last1=Gelvin |editor-first1=James L. |editor-last2=Green |editor-first2=Nile |title=Global Muslims in the Age of Steam and Print |publisher=University of California Press |date=2013 |pages=264 |chapter=Taking 'Abduh to China: Chinese-Egyptian Intellectual Contact in the Early Twentieth Century |isbn=978-1-234-56789-7}}</ref> It was this that allowed him to keep his professorship and post in the PPCC until his death in 1978, despite widespread persecution of Muslims during the upheaval of the [[Cultural Revolution]].<ref>{{cite book |last1=Boyle |first1=Kevin |last2=Sheen |first2=Juliet |date=2013 |title=Freedom of Religion and Belief: A World Report |location=London |publisher=Routledge |page=183}}</ref> Following his death, Jian's translation of [[Philip K. Hitti]]'s [[History of the Arabs (book)|History of the Arabs]] was published in 1979 by the [[Commercial Press]].<ref>{{cite journal |last=Zhixue |first=Ma |date=2008 |url=http://www.mesi.shisu.edu.cn/_upload/article/1d/5d/1cde03e04dc083c0a7d481129f92/decdc0b0-a303-4cce-a284-2cb70ba51fdf.pdf |title=The Latest Edition of ''History of the Arabs'': Prefaces and Postscript |journal=Arab World Studies |volume=5 |pages=81}}</ref> The [[China Social Sciences Press]] also posthumously printed, in 1981, his complete translation of the Qur'an, which Jian had worked on up until 1957, and then between 1976 and 1978.<ref>{{cite news |last=Petersen |first=Kristian |title=Qur'anic Interpretation in China |url=http://www.oxfordislamicstudies.com/article/opr/t343/e0154 |newspaper=Oxford Islamic Studies Online |access-date=February 15, 2017}}</ref>
== Influence == Ma Jian has been praised for his 'two-way' contribution to [[Sino-Arab relations|Sino-Arab]] [[Cultural exchange|cross-cultural exchange]] - that is, his translations of [[Confucianism|Confucian]] literature into Arabic, and Quran into Chinese.
His translation of the Qur'an remains the most popular in China today, surpassing versions by [[Wang Jingzhai]] and Li Tiezheng.<ref>{{cite journal |last=Wang |first=Jin |date=2016 |title=Middle East Studies in China: Achievements and Problems |url=http://www.rubincenter.org/wp-content/uploads/2016/09/06_Wang-tz-au-TZ-PDF.pdf |journal=Middle East Review of International Affairs |volume=20 |issue=2 |pages=51}}</ref> It has been lauded for its faithfulness to the original, and has reached an 'almost canonical status'.<ref>Spiro, 23-24.</ref> The quality of this translation has also been recognised internationally - with the [[Medina]]-based [[King Fahd Complex for the Printing of the Holy Quran|King Fahd Holy Qur'an Printing Press]] opting to use it for their Arabic-Chinese bilingual edition of the Quran, published in 1987.<ref>Petersen.</ref>
